front.title: Normal Force
front.question: What is the normal force and its direction relative to the surface?

cards.back: The force exerted by a surface on an object in contact with it.  It's perpendicular to the surface.

front.title: Frictional Force
front.question: Describe frictional force and its relationship to the normal force.

cards.back: A force opposing motion between surfaces in contact. Its magnitude is proportional to the normal force.

front.title: Coefficients of Friction
front.question: What are Œºs and Œºk, and how are they used?

cards.back: Œºs (coefficient of static friction) and Œºk (coefficient of kinetic friction) are constants determining the magnitude of frictional force given the normal force.  Œºs applies when objects are at rest, Œºk when they're moving.

front.title: Force Components on a Slope
front.question: How are the components of gravity (Fg) resolved parallel and perpendicular to a slope?

cards.back:
Fg sin(Œ∏)
 Fgx = ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ
           1

      Fg cos(Œ∏)
 Fgy = ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ
           1

front.title: Newton's First Law
front.question: State Newton's First Law of Motion.

cards.back: An object at rest stays at rest and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and in the same direction unless acted upon by an unbalanced force.

front.title: Newton's Second Law
front.question: State Newton's Second Law and give its formula.

cards.back:
The acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the net force acting on the object, is in the same direction as the net force, and is inversely proportional to the mass of the object.

`Fnet = ma`

front.title: Newton's Third Law
front.question: State Newton's Third Law of Motion.

cards.back: For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.

front.title: Newton's Law of Universal Gravitation
front.question: State Newton's Law of Universal Gravitation and provide its formula.

cards.back:
Every particle attracts every other particle in the universe with a force which is directly proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between their centers.

      Gm1m2
 F = ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ
       d^2

front.title: Electromagnetism
front.question: What is electromagnetism?

cards.back: The study of the properties and relationship between electric currents and magnetism.

front.title: Magnetic Field around a Conductor
front.question: What happens when a current flows through a conductor?

cards.back: A magnetic field is produced around the conductor.

front.title: Right Hand Rule
front.question: How do you determine the direction of the magnetic field around a current-carrying conductor?

cards.back: Use the Right Hand Rule.

front.title: Electromagnet
front.question: What is an electromagnet?

cards.back: A temporary magnet created by a current-carrying conductor.

front.title: Magnetic Flux
front.question: How is magnetic flux calculated?

cards.back: Magnetic flux (Œ¶) = BAcos(Œ∏), where B is the magnetic field, A is the surface area, and Œ∏ is the angle between the field and the surface normal.

front.title: Electromagnetic Induction
front.question: What is electromagnetic induction?

cards.back: The generation of a voltage in a conductor due to a changing magnetic field.

front.title: Faraday's Law of Electromagnetic Induction
front.question: State Faraday's Law of Electromagnetic Induction.

cards.back: The magnitude of the induced emf (Œµ) is given by: Œµ = -N(ŒîŒ¶/Œît), where N is the number of turns, and ŒîŒ¶/Œît is the rate of change of magnetic flux.

front.title: Units in Electromagnetism
front.question: What are the units for induced emf, magnetic field, and magnetic flux?

cards.back:
| Quantity | Unit Name | Unit Symbol |
|---|---|---|
| Induced emf (Œµ) | Volt | V |
| Magnetic field (B) | Tesla | T |
| Magnetic flux (Œ¶) | Weber | Wb |
| Time (t) | seconds | s |

front.title: Ohm's Law
front.question: State Ohm's Law and write its formula.

cards.back: Ohm's Law states that the current through a conductor is proportional to the voltage across it, at constant temperature.  Formula:  `I = V/R`

front.title: Ohmic vs. Non-Ohmic Conductors
front.question: What is the difference between ohmic and non-ohmic conductors?

cards.back: Ohmic conductors obey Ohm's Law; their resistance is constant. Non-ohmic conductors do not obey Ohm's Law; their resistance changes with voltage or current.

front.title: Calculating Resistance
front.question: How do you calculate the resistance of a resistor using Ohm's Law?

cards.back: Formula: `R = V/I`

front.title: Resistors in Series
front.question: How do you calculate the equivalent resistance of resistors connected in series?

cards.back: Formula: `Rs = R1 + R2 + R3 + ... + Rn`

front.title: Resistors in Parallel
front.question: How do you calculate the equivalent resistance of resistors connected in parallel?

front.title: Electrical Power
front.question: Define electrical power and give three formulas for calculating it.

cards.back: Electrical power is the rate of electrical energy conversion. Formulas: `P = VI`, `P = I¬≤R`, `P = V¬≤/R`

front.title: Electrical Energy
front.question: How do you calculate electrical energy dissipated in a circuit?

cards.back: Formula: `E = Pt`

front.title: Kilowatt Hour
front.question: What is a kilowatt-hour (kWh)?

cards.back: A kilowatt-hour is the energy used by a 1 kW device operating for one hour.

front.title: Bond Energy
front.question: What is bond energy and how is it measured?

cards.back: Bond energy is the amount of energy required to break a chemical bond between two atoms. It's measured in kJ¬∑mol‚Åª¬π.

front.title: Enthalpy
front.question: What does enthalpy (H) represent?

cards.back: Enthalpy is a measure of the total energy of a chemical system at constant pressure.

front.title: Exothermic Reaction
front.question: Describe an exothermic reaction and its enthalpy change (ŒîH).

cards.back: An exothermic reaction releases energy as heat or light.  The energy of the products is less than the energy of the reactants, resulting in a negative ŒîH (ŒîH < 0).

front.title: Endothermic Reaction
front.question: Describe an endothermic reaction and its enthalpy change (ŒîH).

cards.back: An endothermic reaction absorbs energy as heat or light. The energy of the products is greater than the energy of the reactants, resulting in a positive ŒîH (ŒîH > 0).

front.title: Heat of Reaction (ŒîH)
front.question: How is the heat of reaction calculated?

cards.back: ŒîH = E<sub>prod</sub> - E<sub>react</sub>, where E<sub>prod</sub> is the energy of the products and E<sub>react</sub> is the energy of the reactants.

front.title: Activation Energy
front.question: What is activation energy?

cards.back: Activation energy is the minimum amount of energy needed to start a chemical reaction.

front.title: Activated Complex
front.question: What is an activated complex?

cards.back: The activated complex (or transition state) is a high-energy, short-lived intermediate state formed during a reaction, where bonds in reactants are breaking and bonds in products are forming.

front.title: Arrhenius Acids and Bases
front.question: Define Arrhenius acids and bases.

cards.back: Arrhenius acid: Increases the concentration of hydronium ions (H‚ÇÉO‚Å∫) in solution. Arrhenius base: Increases the concentration of hydroxide ions (OH‚Åª) in solution.  This definition is limited to aqueous solutions.

front.title: Br√∏nsted-Lowry Acids and Bases
front.question: Define Br√∏nsted-Lowry acids and bases.

cards.back: Br√∏nsted-Lowry acid: Proton (H‚Å∫) donor. Br√∏nsted-Lowry base: Proton (H‚Å∫) acceptor.

front.title: Amphoteric Substance
front.question: What is an amphoteric substance?

cards.back: A substance that can act as both an acid and a base. Water (H‚ÇÇO) is an example.

front.title: Amphiprotic Substance
front.question: What is an amphiprotic substance?

cards.back: A substance that can act as both a proton donor and a proton acceptor. HCO‚ÇÉ‚Åª and HSO‚ÇÑ‚Åª are examples.

front.title: Conjugate Acid-Base Pair
front.question: What is a conjugate acid-base pair?

cards.back: Two species that differ by a single proton (H‚Å∫). One is an acid, the other its conjugate base (or vice versa).

front.title: Neutralization Reaction
front.question: What is a neutralization reaction?

cards.back: A reaction between an acid and a base.

front.title: Acid-Metal Hydroxide Reaction
front.question: What are the products of an acid reacting with a metal hydroxide?

cards.back: A salt and water.

front.title: Acid-Metal Oxide Reaction
front.question: What are the products of an acid reacting with a metal oxide?

cards.back: A salt and water.

front.title: Acid-Metal Carbonate Reaction
front.question: What are the products of an acid reacting with a metal carbonate?

cards.back: A salt, water, and carbon dioxide.

front.title: Oxidation
front.question: Define oxidation.

cards.back: Loss of electrons.

front.title: Reduction
front.question: Define reduction.

cards.back: Gain of electrons.

front.title: Redox Reaction
front.question: What is a redox reaction?

cards.back: A reaction involving both oxidation and reduction; a transfer of electrons.

front.title: Oxidation Number
front.question: What is an oxidation number?

cards.back: The charge an atom would have if the compound were composed entirely of ions.

front.title: Oxidizing and Reducing Agents
front.question: Define oxidizing and reducing agents.

cards.back: Oxidizing agent: The species that is reduced (gains electrons). Reducing agent: The species that is oxidized (loses electrons).

front.title: Half-Reaction
front.question: What is a half-reaction?

cards.back: Either the oxidation or reduction portion of a redox reaction.

front.title: Lithosphere
front.question: What is the Earth's lithosphere composed of?

cards.back: The lithosphere is the rigid outer part of the Earth, consisting of the crust and upper mantle.

front.title: Mineral Resources
front.question: What are some examples of mineral resources found in the lithosphere?

cards.back: The lithosphere is a rich source of many minerals, which can be extracted through mining.

front.title: Environmental Impact of Mining
front.question: What is the environmental impact of mining and mineral use?

cards.back: Mining and mineral use have a significant impact on the environment.

front.title: Other Lithosphere Resources
front.question: Besides minerals, what other resources are found in the lithosphere?

cards.back: Fuels are another important resource found within the lithosphere.

front.title: Chemical Bond
front.question: What is a chemical bond?

cards.back: A physical process causing atoms to attract and bind in new compounds. Atoms bond to fill their outer valence shell.

front.title: Forces in Bonding
front.question: What forces act between atoms in a bond?

cards.back: Attractive forces between nuclei and electrons; repulsive forces between like-charged electrons and nuclei.  The balance of these forces determines bond energy.

front.title: Lewis Diagrams
front.question: What are Lewis diagrams?

cards.back: Representations of molecular structure using dots or crosses for valence electrons around a central atom.

front.title: Covalent Bond
front.question: What is a covalent bond?

cards.back: A bond where pairs of electrons are shared between two atoms. Single, double, and triple bonds exist depending on the number of shared electron pairs.

front.title: Dative Covalent Bond
front.question: What is a dative covalent bond?

cards.back: A covalent bond where both shared electrons come from the same atom. Examples: hydronium (H‚ÇÉO‚Å∫) and ammonium (NH‚ÇÑ‚Å∫) ions.

front.title: VSEPR Theory
front.question: What does VSEPR theory predict?

cards.back: Predicts the shape of molecules by minimizing electron-pair repulsion around the central atom.

front.title: Electronegativity
front.question: What is electronegativity?

cards.back: An atom's power to attract electrons towards itself in a chemical bond.

front.title: Polar vs. Non-polar Covalent Bonds
front.question: What's the difference between polar and non-polar covalent bonds?

cards.back: Polar bonds are between non-identical atoms (different electronegativity); non-polar bonds are between identical atoms or atoms with the same electronegativity.

front.title: Polar vs. Non-polar Molecules
front.question: What is the difference between polar and non-polar molecules?

cards.back: Polar molecules have uneven charge distribution; non-polar molecules have even charge distribution or symmetrical polar bonds.

front.title: Bond Length and Energy
front.question: Define bond length and bond energy.

cards.back: Bond length: distance between nuclei of bonded atoms. Bond energy: energy needed to break a bond.

front.title: Bond Strength
front.question: What factors affect bond strength?

cards.back: Bond length, atom size, and number of bonds between atoms.

front.title: Intermolecular Forces
front.question: What are intermolecular forces?

cards.back: Forces of attraction between molecules.  Their strength influences a substance's properties.

front.title: Polar Molecules
front.question: What characterizes a polar molecule?

cards.back: Unequal distribution of charge; one part is slightly positive, the other slightly negative (a dipole).

front.title: Non-polar Molecules
front.question: What characterizes a non-polar molecule?

cards.back: Equal distribution of charge.

front.title: Types of Intermolecular Forces
front.question: List the five main types of intermolecular forces.

cards.back: Ion-dipole, ion-induced dipole, dipole-dipole, dipole-induced dipole, induced dipole (London dispersion).

front.title: Ion-Dipole Forces
front.question: Describe ion-dipole forces.

cards.back: Attraction between an ion and a polar molecule.

front.title: Ion-Induced Dipole Forces
front.question: Describe ion-induced dipole forces.

cards.back: An ion induces a temporary dipole in a non-polar molecule.

front.title: Dipole-Dipole Forces
front.question: Describe dipole-dipole forces.

cards.back: Attraction between two polar molecules.

front.title: Dipole-Induced Dipole Forces
front.question: Describe dipole-induced dipole forces.

cards.back: A polar molecule induces a temporary dipole in a non-polar molecule.

front.title: Induced Dipole Forces (London Dispersion Forces)
front.question: Describe induced dipole forces.

cards.back: Temporary dipoles induced in non-polar molecules due to fluctuating electron distribution.

front.title: Van der Waals Forces
front.question: What are van der Waals forces?

cards.back: A collective term for dipole-dipole, dipole-induced dipole, and induced dipole forces.

front.title: Hydrogen Bonds
front.question: Describe hydrogen bonds.

cards.back: A strong type of dipole-dipole force involving hydrogen bonded to a highly electronegative atom (O, F, N).

front.title: Intermolecular Forces and Properties
front.question: How do intermolecular forces affect the properties of substances?

cards.back: Stronger intermolecular forces lead to higher melting/boiling points, higher viscosity, higher density, and lower thermal expansion.

front.title: Water's Properties
front.question: What unique properties does water possess due to its strong hydrogen bonds?

cards.back: High specific heat, infrared radiation absorption, wide liquid range, high heat of vaporization, less dense solid phase.

front.title: Specific Heat
front.question: What is specific heat?

cards.back: The amount of heat needed to raise the temperature of a unit mass by one degree.

front.title: Heat of Vaporization
front.question: What is heat of vaporization?

cards.back: The energy needed to change a given quantity of a substance into a gas.

front.title: Reflection and the Law of Reflection
front.question: Describe the law of reflection.

cards.back: The angle of incidence equals the angle of reflection.  These angles are measured relative to the normal (a line perpendicular to the reflecting surface).

front.title: Speed of Light
front.question: Where does light travel fastest?

cards.back: Light travels fastest in a vacuum. It travels slower in other media.

front.title: Refraction and Refractive Index
front.question: What is refraction, and what influences it?

cards.back: Refraction is the bending of light as it passes from one medium to another. The refractive index of a medium determines the degree of bending.  A higher refractive index indicates greater bending.

front.title: Sketching Ray Diagrams
front.question: How do ray diagrams depict light's path through different media?

cards.back: Ray diagrams use lines to show the path of light. The bending of these lines at the interface between media illustrates refraction, with the degree of bending determined by the refractive indices.

front.title: Snell's Law
front.question: State Snell's Law and explain its use.

cards.back:
Snell's Law:  ```math
 n‚ÇÅsinŒ∏‚ÇÅ = n‚ÇÇsinŒ∏‚ÇÇ ```
where n‚ÇÅ and n‚ÇÇ are the refractive indices of the two media, and Œ∏‚ÇÅ and Œ∏‚ÇÇ are the angles of incidence and refraction, respectively.  It allows calculation of the angle of refraction or the refractive index of a medium.

front.title: Total Internal Reflection
front.question: What conditions are necessary for total internal reflection?

cards.back: Total internal reflection occurs when light travels from a denser medium to a less dense medium, and the angle of incidence exceeds the critical angle.  No light is refracted; all light is reflected back into the denser medium.

front.title: Law of Reflection
front.question: What is the relationship between the angle of incidence and the angle of reflection?

cards.back: The angle of incidence (Œ∏·µ¢) equals the angle of reflection (Œ∏·µ£).  The incident ray, reflected ray, and normal all lie in the same plane.

front.title: Refractive Index
front.question: Define refractive index and provide its formula.

cards.back: The refractive index (n) is the ratio of the speed of light in a vacuum (c) to its speed in a material (v).  Formula:  `n = c/v`

front.title: Snell's Law
front.question: State Snell's Law and explain what it describes.

cards.back: Snell's Law describes the relationship between refractive indices and angles in refraction: `n‚ÇÅ sin Œ∏‚ÇÅ = n‚ÇÇ sin Œ∏‚ÇÇ` where n‚ÇÅ and n‚ÇÇ are the refractive indices of the two media, and Œ∏‚ÇÅ and Œ∏‚ÇÇ are the angles of incidence and refraction respectively.

front.title: Critical Angle
front.question: What is the critical angle, and what phenomenon does it relate to?

cards.back: The critical angle is the angle of incidence at which the angle of refraction is 90¬∞. It's the angle at which total internal reflection begins.

front.title: Total Internal Reflection
front.question: When does total internal reflection occur?

cards.back: Total internal reflection occurs when light travels from a denser medium to a less dense medium, and the angle of incidence is greater than the critical angle.  No light is refracted; all light is reflected internally.

front.title: Wavefront
front.question: What is a wavefront?

cards.back: An imaginary line connecting points on a wave that are in phase.

front.title: Huygens' Principle
front.question: State Huygens' Principle.

cards.back: Every point on a wavefront acts as a source of secondary spherical wavelets.  The new wavefront is the surface tangent to these wavelets.

front.title: Diffraction
front.question: What is diffraction?

cards.back: The bending of waves as they pass through an aperture or around an obstacle.

front.title: Diffraction and Wavelength/Slit Width
front.question: How does the degree of diffraction relate to wavelength and slit width?

cards.back: Diffraction is proportional to the ratio of wavelength (Œª) to slit width (w):  Diffraction ‚àù Œª/w

contents.title: Kinetic Theory of Gases and Gas Laws

front.title: Kinetic Theory of Gases
front.question: What are the main tenets of the Kinetic Theory of Gases?

cards.back: Gases are composed of constantly moving particles with negligible volume and intermolecular forces.  Pressure results from particle collisions, and temperature reflects average kinetic energy.

front.title: Ideal Gas
front.question: What defines an ideal gas?

cards.back: An ideal gas consists of identical particles with zero volume and no intermolecular forces.  Particles move at the same speed.

front.title: Real Gas
front.question: How do real gases deviate from ideal gas behavior?

cards.back: Real gases deviate from ideal behavior at high pressures (particle volume becomes significant) and low temperatures (intermolecular forces become significant).

front.title: Boyle's Law
front.question: State Boyle's Law and write the formula.

cards.back: At constant temperature, the pressure of a fixed amount of gas is inversely proportional to its volume.  `p‚ÇÅV‚ÇÅ = p‚ÇÇV‚ÇÇ`

front.title: Charles' Law
front.question: State Charles' Law and write the formula.

cards.back: At constant pressure, the volume of a fixed amount of gas is directly proportional to its Kelvin temperature. `V‚ÇÅ/T‚ÇÅ = V‚ÇÇ/T‚ÇÇ`

front.title: Pressure-Temperature Relationship
front.question: Describe the relationship between pressure and temperature for a fixed volume of gas.

cards.back: At constant volume, the pressure of a fixed amount of gas is directly proportional to its Kelvin temperature. `p‚ÇÅ/T‚ÇÅ = p‚ÇÇ/T‚ÇÇ`

front.title: Kelvin Temperature Conversion
front.question: How do you convert Celsius to Kelvin?

cards.back: T<sub>K</sub> = T<sub>C</sub> + 273

front.title: General Gas Equation
front.question: State the general gas equation.

cards.back: `p‚ÇÅV‚ÇÅ/T‚ÇÅ = p‚ÇÇV‚ÇÇ/T‚ÇÇ`

front.title: Avogadro's Law
front.question: State Avogadro's Law.

cards.back: Equal volumes of gases at the same temperature and pressure contain the same number of molecules.

front.title: Ideal Gas Equation
front.question: State the ideal gas equation and define each variable.

cards.back: pV = nRT, where p = pressure, V = volume, n = number of moles, R = universal gas constant, T = Kelvin temperature.

front.title: Universal Gas Constant (R)
front.question: What is the value of the universal gas constant (R) and its units?

cards.back: R = 8.314 J¬∑K‚Åª¬π¬∑mol‚Åª¬π

front.title: Molar Volume of Gas at STP
front.question: What is the volume occupied by one mole of any gas at Standard Temperature and Pressure (STP)?

front.title: Volume of Gas at STP
front.question: How do you calculate the volume of 'n' moles of gas at STP?

cards.back: V<sub>g</sub> = 22.4n<sub>g</sub>, where V<sub>g</sub> is the volume in dm¬≥ and n<sub>g</sub> is the number of moles.

front.title: Volume Relationship in Gas Reactions
front.question: What is the formula describing the volume relationship between two gases (A and B) in a reaction?

cards.back: V<sub>A</sub> = (a/b)V<sub>B</sub>, where V<sub>A</sub> and V<sub>B</sub> are the volumes of gases A and B, and 'a' and 'b' are their stoichiometric coefficients.

front.title: Concentration of a Solution
front.question: How is the concentration (c) of a solution calculated?

cards.back: c = n/V, where c is the concentration in mol¬∑dm‚Åª¬≥, n is the number of moles of solute, and V is the volume of the solution in dm¬≥.

front.title: Standard Solution
front.question: What is a standard solution?

cards.back: A solution with a precisely known concentration.

front.title: Titration Calculation
front.question: What formula relates the concentrations and volumes of two solutions in a titration?

cards.back:
```math
(c<sub>A</sub>V<sub>A</sub>)/a = (c<sub>B</sub>V<sub>B</sub>)/b
```
where c<sub>A</sub> and c<sub>B</sub> are the concentrations, V<sub>A</sub> and V<sub>B</sub> are the volumes, and a and b are the stoichiometric coefficients of reactants A and B.

front.title: Limiting Reagent
front.question: What is a limiting reagent?

cards.back: The reactant that is completely consumed in a chemical reaction, limiting the amount of product formed.

front.title: Excess Reagent
front.question: What is an excess reagent?

cards.back: The reactant that is not completely consumed in a chemical reaction.

front.title: Percent Yield
front.question: How is percent yield calculated?

cards.back:
```math
% yield = (actual yield / theoretical yield) * 100
```

front.title: Empirical Formula
front.question: What is an empirical formula?

cards.back: The simplest whole-number ratio of atoms in a compound.

front.title: Molecular Formula
front.question: What is a molecular formula?

cards.back: The actual number of atoms of each element in a molecule of a compound.

front.title: Percent Purity
front.question: How is percent purity calculated?

cards.back:
```math
% purity = (mass of compound / mass of sample) * 100
```

front.title: Electric Charge
front.question: What are the three types of electric charge?

cards.back: Objects can be positively charged, negatively charged, or neutral.

front.title: Coulomb's Law
front.question: State Coulomb's Law.

front.title: Electric Field
front.question: What is an electric field?

cards.back: A region of space where an electric charge experiences a force. The direction of the field at a point is the direction a positive test charge would move if placed at that point.

front.title: Electric Field Lines
front.question: How are electric field lines represented?

cards.back: Electric field lines point away from positive charges and towards negative charges.  This illustrates that like charges repel and unlike charges attract.

front.title: Electric Field Strength
front.question: Define electric field strength (E).

front.title: Electric Field due to a Point Charge
front.question: What is the formula for the electric field due to a point charge Q?

front.title: Electrostatic Force
front.question: Describe the nature of the electrostatic force.

cards.back: The electrostatic force is attractive between unlike charges and repulsive between like charges.

front.title: Medicines
front.question: How is a medicine defined in terms of its purpose and claims?

cards.back: Any substance or mixture of substances used, manufactured, sold, or represented as suitable for diagnosing, treating, mitigating, or preventing disease, or modifying any physical, mental, or organic function in humans or animals. It includes substances that claim medicinal effects even without making explicit claims.

front.title: Advertisement
front.question: What qualifies as an advertisement for a medicine?

cards.back: Any written, pictorial, visual, verbal, or descriptive material that appears in publications, TV, cinema, or is distributed to the public in any way to promote the sale of the medicine.

front.title: Clinical Trial
front.question: What is a clinical trial and what does it involve?

cards.back: A systematic study in humans or animals to establish the efficacy of medicines, verify effects or adverse reactions, and study absorption, distribution, metabolism, and excretion.

front.title: Sell
front.question: What actions are included in the definition of 'sell'?

cards.back: Includes wholesale, retail, import, export, advertise, label, prepare, expose, possess for sale, smuggle, administer, hawk, supply, barter, deliver, transmit as gift or sample, or dispose of in any way.

front.title: Possess
front.question: What does 'possess' mean in the legal context of medicines?

cards.back: To keep, store, or have in custody, control, or supervision. Liability may extend to individuals responsible for those flouting the law under their control.

front.title: Deal In
front.question: What does 'deal in' prohibited drugs involve?

cards.back: Selling or performing any act (as principal, agent, messenger, etc.) related to delivery, collection, import/export, administration, manufacture, or transmission of a prohibited drug.

front.title: Manufacture
front.question: What is considered 'manufacture' of medicine, and who is allowed to compound?

cards.back: Includes compounding, processing, or packing for sale. Excludes compounding by a licensed practitioner or pharmacist for a specific patient or for sale from the premises. MCAZ approval is required for general sale. Prohibited substances cannot be compounded.

front.title: Dispense
front.question: What does it mean to 'dispense' a medicine?

cards.back: To prepare, measure, mix, dissolve, or count out a drug for the treatment of a specific person or animal. Does not include the actual administration of the drug.

front.title: Prescription
front.question: What is a prescription and who is it intended for?

cards.back: An order made by a prescriber, written or verbal, for supplying a medicine to a specific person or animal. It must not be made out to groups like families or clinics. Dangerous Drugs prescriptions must be handwritten.

front.title: Prescriber
front.question: Who is legally allowed to prescribe medicine?

cards.back: Only medical, dental, and veterinary practitioners. Pharmacists and nurses cannot prescribe but may supply certain medicines as permitted by law.

front.title: Dangerous Drugs Register
front.question: What are the requirements for a Dangerous Drugs Register?

cards.back: Must be a bound book, not loose-leaf or card index. Records must comply with Sections 9, 28, and 33 of the Dangerous Drugs Regulations.

front.title: Continuous and Personal Supervision
front.question: What is required under continuous and personal supervision?

cards.back: All regulated activities must occur under the presence and active supervision of a person with a valid Persons Licence issued by MCAZ, who is authorized to dispense medicines.

front.title: Definition of Meiosis
front.question: What is meiosis?

cards.back: Meiosis is a type of cell division where a diploid cell divides to form four genetically different haploid cells (sex cells).

front.title: Purpose of Meiosis
front.question: What is the significance of meiosis?

cards.back: It halves the number of chromosomes (from diploid to haploid), ensuring the correct number in the zygote after fertilization, and it introduces genetic variation through crossing over.

front.title: Meiosis I
front.question: What happens during Meiosis I?

cards.back: Homologous chromosomes separate, resulting in two haploid cells with duplicated chromosomes.

front.title: Meiosis II
front.question: What happens during Meiosis II?

cards.back: Sister chromatids separate, forming four genetically different haploid cells.

front.title: Crossing Over
front.question: What is crossing over?

cards.back: During Prophase I, chromatids of homologous chromosomes exchange segments at the chiasma, leading to genetic variation.

front.title: Non-Disjunction
front.question: What is non-disjunction?

cards.back: It is the failure of chromosomes to separate properly during Anaphase I or II, which can lead to disorders like Down syndrome.

front.title: Meiosis vs Mitosis
front.question: How is meiosis different from mitosis?

cards.back: Meiosis produces four haploid, genetically different cells; mitosis produces two diploid, genetically identical cells.

front.title: What is Evolution?
front.question: Define evolution in biological terms.

cards.back: Evolution is the change in the characteristics of a species over generations through natural selection and other processes.

front.title: Natural Selection
front.question: What is natural selection?

cards.back: Natural selection is the process by which organisms better adapted to their environment survive and reproduce, passing on advantageous traits.

front.title: Variation
front.question: What causes variation in a population?

cards.back: Variation is caused by mutations, genetic recombination, and random fertilisation.

front.title: Speciation
front.question: How does speciation occur?

cards.back: Speciation occurs when populations become reproductively isolated and evolve independently into new species.

front.title: Evidence for Evolution
front.question: What evidence supports the theory of evolution?

cards.back: Fossil records, comparative anatomy, DNA similarities, and embryology all support evolution.

front.title: Biodiversity
front.question: What is biodiversity and why is it important?

cards.back: Biodiversity refers to the variety of life in all its forms. It ensures ecosystem stability and resilience.

front.title: Deforestation
front.question: How does deforestation affect the environment?

cards.back: It leads to habitat loss, reduced biodiversity, soil erosion, and contributes to climate change.

front.title: Greenhouse Effect
front.question: What causes the enhanced greenhouse effect?

cards.back: Human activities like burning fossil fuels increase greenhouse gases (CO‚ÇÇ, CH‚ÇÑ), leading to global warming.

front.title: Eutrophication
front.question: What is eutrophication and what causes it?

cards.back: Excess nutrients from fertilizers enter water bodies, causing algae blooms that deplete oxygen and kill aquatic life.

front.title: Sustainable Living
front.question: How can we reduce our impact on the environment?

cards.back: By conserving resources, reducing waste, recycling, and using renewable energy sources.

front.title: Scientific Method
front.question: What are the steps of the scientific method?

cards.back: Identify a problem, formulate a hypothesis, conduct an experiment, collect data, analyze results, and draw a conclusion.

front.title: Controlled Variables
front.question: What are controlled variables?

cards.back: Controlled variables are factors kept constant to ensure a fair test in an experiment.

front.title: Graph Interpretation
front.question: What should you include when drawing a graph?

cards.back: A title, labeled axes with units, appropriate scale, and a key if necessary.

front.title: Accuracy vs Precision
front.question: What is the difference between accuracy and precision?

cards.back: Accuracy is how close a result is to the true value; precision is how consistently results can be repeated.

front.title: Essay Writing in Science
front.question: What is the basic structure for writing a scientific essay?

cards.back: Introduction, body (with logical arguments and evidence), and conclusion.

front.title: What are nucleic acids?
front.question: What are the two types of nucleic acids found in cells?

cards.back: The two types of nucleic acids are DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) and RNA (ribonucleic acid).

front.title: DNA vs RNA
front.question: What is the main difference between DNA and RNA?

cards.back: DNA is double-stranded and contains thymine; RNA is single-stranded and contains uracil instead of thymine.

front.title: Structure of DNA
front.question: What are the building blocks of DNA?

cards.back: DNA is made up of nucleotides, which consist of a phosphate group, a deoxyribose sugar, and a nitrogenous base.

front.title: Nitrogenous Bases
front.question: Which bases pair in DNA and RNA?

cards.back: In DNA: A pairs with T, and G pairs with C. In RNA: A pairs with U, and G pairs with C.

front.title: DNA Replication
front.question: Why is DNA replication important?

cards.back: DNA replication ensures that each new cell has an exact copy of the DNA, preserving genetic information.

front.title: Protein Synthesis
front.question: What are the two main stages of protein synthesis?

cards.back: Transcription (in the nucleus) and translation (in the cytoplasm at the ribosome).

front.title: mRNA and tRNA
front.question: What are the roles of mRNA and tRNA in protein synthesis?

cards.back: mRNA carries the genetic code from DNA to the ribosome; tRNA brings amino acids and matches codons with anticodons.

front.title: Codons
front.question: What is a codon?

cards.back: A codon is a sequence of three bases on mRNA that codes for a specific amino acid.

front.title: DNA Profiling
front.question: What is DNA profiling used for?

cards.back: DNA profiling is used to identify individuals in criminal cases, paternity tests, and identifying remains.

front.title: External Fertilisation
front.question: What is external fertilisation?

cards.back: It is when sperm fertilises the egg outside the body, usually in water, allowing sperm to swim to the egg.

front.title: Internal Fertilisation
front.question: Why is internal fertilisation advantageous?

cards.back: It allows fertilisation in dry environments and increases the likelihood of successful reproduction.

front.title: Ovipary vs Vivipary
front.question: What is the difference between ovipary and vivipary?

cards.back: Ovipary involves laying eggs; vivipary involves live birth after internal development of the embryo.

front.title: Function of Testes
front.question: What do the testes produce?

cards.back: Sperm cells and the hormone testosterone.

front.title: Structure of Sperm
front.question: What are the parts of a sperm cell and their functions?

cards.back: Acrosome (enzymes), nucleus (DNA), mitochondria (energy), tail (movement).

front.title: Menstrual Cycle
front.question: What are the main phases of the menstrual cycle?

cards.back: Menstruation, follicular phase, ovulation, luteal phase.

front.title: Gene
front.question: What is a gene?

cards.back: A small portion of DNA that codes for a particular characteristic. Found inside the chromosome, located in the nucleus of a cell.

front.title: Alleles
front.question: What are alleles?

cards.back: Different forms of a gene at the same locus on homologous chromosomes. Example: Dominant (T) ‚Äì tall, Recessive (t) ‚Äì short.

front.title: Genotype
front.question: What is a genotype?

cards.back: The genetic makeup of an organism. Examples: TT (homozygous dominant), Tt (heterozygous), tt (homozygous recessive).

front.title: Phenotype
front.question: What is a phenotype?

cards.back: The physical appearance of an organism determined by its genotype. Example: Tall or short plants.

front.title: Dominant Allele
front.question: What is a dominant allele?

cards.back: An allele that is expressed in the phenotype when present in homozygous (TT) or heterozygous (Tt) form. Example: T for tall.

front.title: Recessive Allele
front.question: What is a recessive allele?

cards.back: An allele masked in the heterozygous condition and only expressed in the homozygous condition. Example: t for short.

front.title: Heterozygous
front.question: What does heterozygous mean?

cards.back: Having two different alleles for a trait. Example: Tt ‚Äì phenotype is tall due to the dominant allele.

front.title: Homozygous
front.question: What does homozygous mean?

cards.back: Having two identical alleles for a trait. Examples: TT ‚Äì tall (dominant), tt ‚Äì short (recessive).

front.title: Monohybrid Cross
front.question: What is a monohybrid cross?

cards.back: A genetic cross examining one characteristic or trait. Example: Flower colour ‚Äì yellow vs white.

front.title: Complete Dominance
front.question: What is complete dominance?

cards.back: A dominant allele fully masks the recessive allele in a heterozygous organism. Example: Tt results in a tall plant because T masks t.

front.title: Incomplete Dominance
front.question: What is incomplete dominance?

cards.back: The offspring shows a phenotype that is intermediate between the parents. Example: Red √ó White flowers ‚Üí Pink flowers.

front.title: Co-dominance
front.question: What is co-dominance?

cards.back: Both alleles are equally expressed in the phenotype. Example: Red √ó White flowers ‚Üí Flowers with red and white patches.

front.title: Multiple Alleles
front.question: What are multiple alleles?

cards.back: More than two alternative forms of a gene exist at the same locus. Example: Blood groups IA, IB, and i.

front.title: Sex-linked Characteristics
front.question: What are sex-linked characteristics?

cards.back: Traits carried on the sex chromosomes (usually X). Example: Haemophilia or colour-blindness ‚Äì X·¥¥X ∞ (carrier female), X ∞Y (affected male).

front.title: Karyotype
front.question: What is a karyotype?

cards.back: The number, shape, and arrangement of chromosomes in the nucleus of a somatic cell. Used to detect chromosomal abnormalities.

front.title: Cloning
front.question: What is cloning?

cards.back: A process to produce genetically identical organisms. Example: Dolly the sheep was cloned from a diploid cell.

front.title: Genetic Modification
front.question: What is genetic modification?

cards.back: Altering genetic material to produce desired traits. Example: Inserting the human insulin gene into bacteria to produce insulin.

front.title: Human Genome
front.question: What is the human genome?

cards.back: A complete map of all genes on human chromosomes. Example: Gene 3 on chromosome 4 controls a specific trait.

front.title: Central Nervous System
front.question: What are the two main parts of the central nervous system?

cards.back: The brain and the spinal cord.

front.title: Reflex Arc
front.question: What is a reflex arc?

cards.back: A pathway that controls an involuntary response to a stimulus, involving a sensory neuron, interneuron, and motor neuron.

front.title: Function of the Cerebellum
front.question: What is the role of the cerebellum in the brain?

cards.back: The cerebellum coordinates voluntary movements and helps maintain posture and balance.

front.title: Sense Organs
front.question: What are the five main sense organs?

cards.back: Eyes, ears, skin, tongue, and nose.

front.title: Homeostasis Link
front.question: How is the nervous system linked to homeostasis?

cards.back: It detects changes in the environment and sends signals to organs to maintain stable internal conditions.

front.title: What is the endocrine system?
front.question: What is the primary function of the endocrine system?

cards.back: The endocrine system regulates body functions by releasing hormones into the bloodstream.

front.title: Hormones
front.question: What are hormones?

cards.back: Hormones are chemical messengers secreted by endocrine glands that affect target organs.

front.title: Glands of the Endocrine System
front.question: Which are the major endocrine glands?

cards.back: Pituitary gland, thyroid gland, adrenal glands, pancreas, ovaries, and testes.

front.title: Pancreas
front.question: What hormones are produced by the pancreas and what do they regulate?

cards.back: Insulin and glucagon; they regulate blood glucose levels.

front.title: Negative Feedback
front.question: What is negative feedback in the endocrine system?

cards.back: A process where the body detects a change and responds to reverse that change, maintaining balance (homeostasis).

front.title: Definition of Homeostasis
front.question: What is homeostasis?

cards.back: Homeostasis is the maintenance of a constant internal environment in the body.

front.title: Importance of Homeostasis
front.question: Why is homeostasis important?

cards.back: It ensures that enzymes and cells function optimally by maintaining stable internal conditions.

front.title: Body Temperature Regulation
front.question: How does the body regulate temperature when it is too hot?

cards.back: By sweating and vasodilation to release heat through the skin.

front.title: Glucose Regulation
front.question: Which hormones regulate blood sugar levels?

cards.back: Insulin lowers blood glucose; glucagon raises it.

front.title: Negative Feedback in Homeostasis
front.question: What is the role of negative feedback in homeostasis?

cards.back: It reverses changes to bring internal conditions back to normal.

front.title: Exponential Notation
front.question: How is a number written in exponential notation?

cards.back: A number is written as a‚Åø, where n is any natural number and a is any real number.  'a' is the base and 'n' is the exponent or index.

front.title: Definition of a‚Å∞
front.question: What is a‚Å∞ equal to?

cards.back: a‚Å∞ = 1, if a ‚â† 0

front.title: Definition of a‚Åª‚Åø
front.question: How is a‚Åª‚Åø defined?

cards.back: a‚Åª‚Åø = 1/a‚Åø, if a ‚â† 0

front.title: Definition of 1/a‚Åª‚Åø
front.question: What is 1/a‚Åª‚Åø equal to?

cards.back: 1/a‚Åª‚Åø = a‚Åø, if a ‚â† 0

front.title: Product of Powers
front.question: What is the rule for multiplying powers with the same base?

cards.back: a·µê √ó a‚Åø = a·µê‚Å∫‚Åø

front.title: Quotient of Powers
front.question: What is the rule for dividing powers with the same base?

cards.back: a·µê / a‚Åø = a·µê‚Åª‚Åø

front.title: Power of a Product
front.question: What is the rule for raising a product to a power?

cards.back: (ab)‚Åø = a‚Åøb‚Åø

front.title: Power of a Quotient
front.question: What is the rule for raising a quotient to a power?

cards.back: (a/b)‚Åø = a‚Åø/b‚Åø

front.title: Power of a Power
front.question: What is the rule for raising a power to another power?

cards.back: (a·µê)‚Åø = a·µê‚Åø

front.title: Simplifying Exponential Expressions
front.question: How do you simplify expressions with exponents?

cards.back: Reduce bases to prime bases or factorize.

front.title: Solving Exponential Equations
front.question: How do you solve equations with exponents?

cards.back: If aÀ£ = a ∏, then x = y; or factorize the expressions.

front.title: Data
front.question: What is data in the context of statistics?

cards.back: Data are pieces of information observed and recorded from experiments or surveys.

front.title: Quantitative Data
front.question: What are quantitative data?

cards.back: Data that can be expressed numerically.  Can be discrete or continuous.

front.title: Qualitative Data
front.question: What are qualitative data?

cards.back: Data that cannot be expressed numerically.  Includes categorical and anecdotal data.

front.title: Mean
front.question: How is the mean calculated?

cards.back:
The sum of a set of values divided by the number of values.
```math
      ‚àë xi
 xÃÑ = ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ
       n
```

front.title: Median
front.question: How is the median determined?

cards.back: The middle value in an ordered data set.  If there's an even number of values, it's the average of the two middle values.

front.title: Mode
front.question: What is the mode of a data set?

cards.back: The value that appears most frequently in a data set.

front.title: Outlier
front.question: What is an outlier?

cards.back: A value significantly different from the other values in a data set.

front.title: Grouping Continuous Data
front.question: How can continuous data be made discrete?

cards.back: By dividing the range of values into sub-ranges (classes) and assigning each value to its respective class.

front.title: Dispersion
front.question: What does dispersion refer to in statistics?

cards.back: Statistics that describe how values are distributed around the center (mean, median).

front.title: Range
front.question: How is the range calculated?

cards.back: The difference between the maximum and minimum values in a data set.

front.title: Percentile
front.question: What is the pth percentile?

cards.back:
The value, v, below which p% of the data falls.  Calculated using:
```math
r = (p/100)(n - 1) + 1
``` where n is the number of values.

front.title: Quartiles
front.question: What are quartiles?

cards.back: Three values (Q1, Q2, Q3) that divide an ordered data set into four equal parts. Q2 is the median.

front.title: Interquartile Range (IQR)
front.question: How is the IQR calculated?

cards.back: The difference between the upper quartile (Q3) and the lower quartile (Q1). Represents the range of the middle 50% of data.

front.title: Semi-Interquartile Range
front.question: How is the semi-IQR calculated?

cards.back: Half of the interquartile range.

front.title: Five-Number Summary
front.question: What constitutes the five-number summary?

cards.back: Minimum value, Q1, Q2 (median), Q3, Maximum value.

front.title: Box-and-Whisker Plot
front.question: What is a box-and-whisker plot?

cards.back: A graphical representation of the five-number summary.

front.title: Trigonometric Ratios
front.question: What are the three basic trigonometric ratios?

cards.back:
The three basic trigonometric ratios for a right-angled triangle are: 

* sine (sin):  opposite/hypotenuse
* cosine (cos): adjacent/hypotenuse
* tangent (tan): opposite/adjacent

front.title: Angle of Elevation
front.question: Define the angle of elevation.

cards.back: The angle of elevation is the angle between the line of sight to an object above the horizontal and the horizontal plane.

front.title: Angle of Depression
front.question: Define the angle of depression.

cards.back: The angle of depression is the angle between the line of sight to an object below the horizontal and the horizontal plane.

front.title: Applications of Trigonometry
front.question: Give an example of how trigonometry is used to solve problems.

cards.back: Trigonometry is used to solve problems involving right-angled triangles in two dimensions. For example, finding the height of a building given the angle of elevation and distance from the base.

front.title: Quadrilateral
front.question: What is a quadrilateral?

cards.back: A closed shape with four straight line segments.

front.title: Parallelogram
front.question: List three properties of a parallelogram.

cards.back:
‚Ä¢ Both pairs of opposite sides are parallel and equal.
‚Ä¢ Both pairs of opposite angles are equal.
‚Ä¢ Diagonals bisect each other.

front.title: Rectangle
front.question: What makes a rectangle different from a parallelogram?

cards.back: All four angles are 90¬∞.  Diagonals are equal in length.

front.title: Rhombus
front.question: What is a rhombus?

cards.back: A parallelogram with all four sides equal in length. Diagonals bisect each other at 90¬∞ and bisect the opposite angles.

front.title: Square
front.question: What is a square?

cards.back: A rhombus with all four angles equal to 90¬∞.

front.title: Trapezium
front.question: What is a trapezium?

cards.back: A quadrilateral with one pair of opposite sides parallel.

front.title: Kite
front.question: Describe a kite and one of its properties.

cards.back: A quadrilateral with two pairs of adjacent sides equal. One pair of opposite angles are equal (the angles between unequal sides).

front.title: Mid-point Theorem
front.question: State the mid-point theorem.

cards.back: The line joining the mid-points of two sides of a triangle is parallel to the third side and half its length.

contents.title: Area, Volume, and Surface Area of Geometric Solids

front.title: Area of a Square
front.question: What is the formula for the area of a square?

cards.back: Area = s¬≤ where s is the side length

front.title: Area of a Rectangle
front.question: How do you calculate the area of a rectangle?

cards.back: Area = b √ó h where b is the base and h is the height

front.title: Area of a Triangle
front.question: What's the formula for the area of a triangle?

cards.back: Area = (1/2) √ó b √ó h where b is the base and h is the height

front.title: Area of a Trapezium
front.question: How do you find the area of a trapezium?

cards.back: Area = (1/2)(a + b) √ó h where a and b are the parallel sides and h is the height

front.title: Area of a Parallelogram
front.question: What is the area formula for a parallelogram?

cards.back: Area = b √ó h where b is the base and h is the height

front.title: Area of a Circle
front.question: Give the formula for the area of a circle.

cards.back: Area = œÄr¬≤ where r is the radius

front.title: Volume of a Rectangular Prism
front.question: How do you calculate the volume of a rectangular prism?

cards.back: Volume = l √ó b √ó h where l is length, b is width, and h is height

front.title: Volume of a Triangular Prism
front.question: What is the formula for the volume of a triangular prism?

cards.back: Volume = (1/2 √ó b √ó h) √ó H where b and h are the base and height of the triangle, and H is the prism's height

front.title: Volume of a Cube
front.question: What is the volume of a cube with side length s?

cards.back: Volume = s¬≥

front.title: Volume of a Cylinder
front.question: Give the formula for the volume of a cylinder.

cards.back: Volume = œÄr¬≤ √ó h where r is the radius and h is the height

front.title: Surface Area of a Square Pyramid
front.question: What is the formula for the surface area of a square pyramid?

cards.back: Surface Area = b(b + 2h) where b is the base side and h is the slant height

front.title: Surface Area of a Triangular Pyramid
front.question: How do you calculate the surface area of a triangular pyramid?

cards.back: Surface Area = (1/2)b(hb + 3hs) where b is the base, hb is the base height, and hs is the slant height

front.title: Surface Area of a Right Cone
front.question: Give the formula for the surface area of a right cone.

cards.back: Surface Area = œÄr(r + hs) where r is the radius and hs is the slant height

front.title: Surface Area of a Sphere
front.question: What is the formula for the surface area of a sphere?

cards.back: Surface Area = 4œÄr¬≤ where r is the radius

front.title: Volume of a Square Pyramid
front.question: What is the volume of a square pyramid?

cards.back: Volume = (1/3) √ó b¬≤ √ó H where b is the base side and H is the height

front.title: Volume of a Triangular Pyramid
front.question: How do you calculate the volume of a triangular pyramid?

cards.back: Volume = (1/3) √ó (1/2 √ó b √ó h) √ó H where b and h are the base and height of the triangle, and H is the pyramid's height

front.title: Volume of a Right Cone
front.question: Give the formula for the volume of a right cone.

cards.back: Volume = (1/3) √ó œÄr¬≤ √ó H where r is the radius and H is the height

front.title: Volume of a Sphere
front.question: What is the formula for the volume of a sphere?

cards.back: Volume = (4/3)œÄr¬≥ where r is the radius

front.title: Experiment
front.question: What is an experiment in probability?

cards.back: An uncertain process.

front.title: Outcome
front.question: What is an outcome in probability?

cards.back: A single result of an experiment.

front.title: Sample Space
front.question: Define sample space and its notation.

cards.back: The set of all possible outcomes of an experiment.  Denoted by S, with size n(S).

front.title: Event
front.question: What is an event in probability?

cards.back: A specific set of outcomes of an experiment. Denoted by E, with size n(E).

front.title: Probability
front.question: Define probability and its range.

cards.back: A real number between 0 and 1 describing the likelihood of an event occurring. 0 means it never occurs, 1 means it always occurs.

front.title: Theoretical Probability
front.question: How do you calculate theoretical probability?

cards.back: When all outcomes are equally likely, it's the ratio of the number of favorable outcomes to the total number of possible outcomes:  P(E) = n(E) / n(S)

front.title: Relative Frequency
front.question: How do you calculate relative frequency?

cards.back: The number of times an event occurs divided by the total number of trials: f = p/n (where p is positive trials and n is total trials).

front.title: Union of Events
front.question: What is the union of two events?

cards.back: A new set containing all elements in at least one of the two sets (A‚à™B or A or B).

front.title: Intersection of Events
front.question: What is the intersection of two events?

cards.back: A new set containing all elements in both sets (A‚à©B or A and B).

front.title: Probability of the Sample Space
front.question: What is the probability of the sample space?

front.title: Probability of the Union of Two Events
front.question: Give the formula for the probability of the union of two events.

cards.back: P(A‚à™B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A‚à©B)

front.title: Mutually Exclusive Events
front.question: Define mutually exclusive events.

cards.back: Two events that cannot occur at the same time.

front.title: Complement of a Set
front.question: What is the complement of a set A?

cards.back: A set containing all elements not in A (A' or not(A)).

front.title: Complementary Events
front.question: What are the characteristics of complementary events?

cards.back: They are mutually exclusive (A‚à©A' = √ò) and their union covers the sample space (A‚à™A' = S). Their probabilities sum to 1: P(A) + P(A') = 1.

front.title: General Term of an Arithmetic Sequence
front.question: How do you express the nth term of an arithmetic sequence?

cards.back: The nth term, T<sub>n</sub>, represents the general term of an arithmetic sequence.

front.title: Common Difference
front.question: How is the common difference (d) of an arithmetic sequence defined?

cards.back: The common difference, d, is the difference between any two consecutive terms:  d = T<sub>n</sub> - T<sub>n-1</sub>

front.title: Formula for the nth term
front.question: What is the general formula to find any term in an arithmetic sequence?

cards.back: While a specific formula isn't provided in the notes,  you can derive one using the common difference. For example, if you know the first term (T<sub>1</sub>) and the common difference (d), the nth term can be calculated as T<sub>n</sub> = T<sub>1</sub> + (n-1)d

contents.title: Linear and Quadratic Equations and Inequalities

front.title: Linear Equation
front.question: What is a linear equation and how many solutions does it have?

cards.back: A linear equation has a variable with an exponent of 1. It has at most one solution.

front.title: Quadratic Equation
front.question: What is a quadratic equation and how many solutions does it have?

cards.back: A quadratic equation has a variable with an exponent of at most 2. It has at most two solutions.

front.title: System of Simultaneous Equations
front.question: How many equations are needed to solve for two unknown variables, and what are the methods to solve them?

cards.back: Two equations are required.  Methods include algebraic solutions (substitution or elimination) and graphical solutions (finding the point of intersection).

front.title: Literal Equations
front.question: What are literal equations?

cards.back: Literal equations contain several letters and variables.

front.title: Linear Inequality
front.question: How is a linear inequality similar to a linear equation, and what happens when multiplying/dividing by a negative number?

cards.back: Similar to a linear equation, but uses inequality symbols (<, >, ‚â§, ‚â•).  When multiplying or dividing both sides by a negative number, the inequality sign reverses.

front.title: Sine, Cosine, Tangent
front.question: Define the trigonometric ratios sin Œ∏, cos Œ∏, and tan Œ∏ for a right-angled triangle.

cards.back:
In a right-angled triangle:

* sin Œ∏ = opposite / hypotenuse = y / r
* cos Œ∏ = adjacent / hypotenuse = x / r
* tan Œ∏ = opposite / adjacent = y / x

front.title: Reciprocal Trigonometric Ratios
front.question: What are the reciprocal trigonometric ratios and how are they defined?

cards.back:
The reciprocal ratios are:

* cosec Œ∏ = 1 / sin Œ∏ = hypotenuse / opposite = r / y
* sec Œ∏ = 1 / cos Œ∏ = hypotenuse / adjacent = r / x
* cot Œ∏ = 1 / tan Œ∏ = adjacent / opposite = x / y

front.title: Solving Trigonometric Equations
front.question: How can we solve simple trigonometric equations?

cards.back: We can use the principles of solving equations and the trigonometric ratios to solve simple trigonometric equations.

front.title: Special Angles
front.question: For which angles can we easily find the values of sin, cos, and tan without a calculator?

cards.back: We can easily find the values of sin, cos, and tan for 0¬∞, 30¬∞, 45¬∞, 60¬∞, and 90¬∞ without a calculator.

front.title: Extending Trigonometric Ratios
front.question: How can the definitions of trigonometric ratios be extended?

cards.back: The definitions of the trigonometric ratios can be extended to any angle.

front.title: Independent and Dependent Variables
front.question: What are independent and dependent variables in a function?

cards.back: The independent variable (x) is freely chosen, while the dependent variable (y) is calculated based on the x-value.

front.title: Domain and Range
front.question: Define the domain and range of a function.

cards.back: The domain is the set of all possible x-values. The range is the set of all resulting y-values.

front.title: Asymptote
front.question: What is an asymptote?

cards.back: An asymptote is a line that a function's graph approaches but never touches.

front.title: Linear Function
front.question: What is the general form of a linear function?

cards.back: y = ax + q

front.title: Parabolic Function
front.question: What is the general form of a parabolic function?

cards.back: y = ax¬≤ + q

front.title: Hyperbolic Function
front.question: What is the general form of a hyperbolic function?

cards.back: y = a/x + q

front.title: Exponential Function
front.question: What is the general form of an exponential function?

cards.back: y = abÀ£ + q

front.title: Trigonometric Functions
front.question: Give examples of general forms for trigonometric functions.

cards.back:
y = a sin Œ∏ + q
y = a cos Œ∏ + q
y = a tan Œ∏ + q

front.title: Quadrilateral
front.question: What is a quadrilateral?

cards.back: A closed shape with four straight line segments.

front.title: Parallelogram
front.question: What are the properties of a parallelogram?

cards.back: Both pairs of opposite sides are parallel and equal in length. Both pairs of opposite angles are equal. Diagonals bisect each other.

front.title: Rectangle
front.question: What are the properties of a rectangle?

cards.back: A parallelogram with all four angles equal to 90¬∞.  Opposite sides are parallel and equal. Diagonals bisect each other and are equal in length.

front.title: Rhombus
front.question: What are the properties of a rhombus?

cards.back: A parallelogram with all four sides equal in length. Opposite angles are equal. Diagonals bisect each other at 90¬∞ and bisect the opposite angles.

front.title: Square
front.question: What are the properties of a square?

cards.back: A rhombus with all four angles equal to 90¬∞.  Opposite sides are parallel. Diagonals bisect each other at 90¬∞ and are equal in length. All interior angles are 90¬∞ and diagonals bisect opposite angles into 45¬∞ angles.

front.title: Trapezium
front.question: What is a trapezium?

cards.back: A quadrilateral with one pair of opposite sides parallel.

front.title: Kite
front.question: What are the properties of a kite?

cards.back: A quadrilateral with two pairs of adjacent sides equal. One pair of opposite angles are equal. The diagonal between equal sides bisects the other diagonal and bisects the interior angles. Diagonals intersect at 90¬∞.

front.title: Mid-point Theorem
front.question: State the mid-point theorem.

cards.back: The line joining the mid-points of two sides of a triangle is parallel to the third side and half its length.

front.title: Point
front.question: How is a point represented?

cards.back: A point is an ordered pair of numbers written as (x, y).

front.title: Distance Formula
front.question: What is the formula for calculating the distance between two points?

cards.back:
```math
d = ‚àö((x‚ÇÅ - x‚ÇÇ)¬≤ + (y‚ÇÅ - y‚ÇÇ)¬≤)
```

front.title: Gradient
front.question: How is the gradient of a line calculated?

cards.back:
The gradient (m) is the ratio of vertical change to horizontal change between two points:
```math
m = (y‚ÇÇ - y‚ÇÅ) / (x‚ÇÇ - x‚ÇÅ)
```

front.title: Equation of a Straight Line
front.question: What is the standard form of the equation of a straight line?

cards.back: y = mx + c, where m is the gradient and c is the y-intercept.

front.title: Equation of a Straight Line (Two-Point Form)
front.question: What is the two-point form of the equation of a straight line?

cards.back:
```math
(y - y‚ÇÅ) / (x - x‚ÇÅ) = (y‚ÇÇ - y‚ÇÅ) / (x‚ÇÇ - x‚ÇÅ)
```

front.title: Parallel Lines
front.question: What is the relationship between the gradients of parallel lines?

cards.back: Parallel lines have equal gradients.

front.title: Perpendicular Lines
front.question: What is the relationship between the gradients of perpendicular lines?

cards.back: The product of the gradients of perpendicular lines is -1.

front.title: Horizontal Line Gradient
front.question: What is the gradient of a horizontal line?

cards.back: The gradient of a horizontal line is 0.

front.title: Vertical Line Gradient
front.question: What is the gradient of a vertical line?

cards.back: The gradient of a vertical line is undefined.

front.title: Midpoint Formula
front.question: What is the formula for finding the midpoint between two points?

cards.back:
```math
M(x, y) = ((x‚ÇÅ + x‚ÇÇ) / 2, (y‚ÇÅ + y‚ÇÇ) / 2)
```

front.title: Simple Interest
front.question: What is the formula for calculating simple interest?

cards.back:
The formula for simple interest is:
```math
 A = P(1 + in)
```
Where:
* A = accumulated amount
* P = principal amount
* i = interest rate (as a decimal)
* n = number of years

front.title: Compound Interest
front.question: How is compound interest calculated?

cards.back:
The formula for compound interest is:
```math
 A = P(1 + i)^n
```
Where:
* A = accumulated amount
* P = principal amount
* i = interest rate (as a decimal)
* n = number of years

front.title: Hire Purchase Repayments
front.question: How are hire purchase loan repayments calculated?

cards.back: Hire purchase loan repayments are calculated using the simple interest formula on the cash price minus the deposit.  Monthly repayments are found by dividing the accumulated amount by the number of months.

front.title: Population Growth/Inflation
front.question: What formula is used to calculate population growth or inflation?

cards.back: Population growth and inflation are calculated using the compound interest formula.

front.title: Foreign Exchange Rate
front.question: What is a foreign exchange rate?

cards.back: A foreign exchange rate is the price of one currency in terms of another.

contents.title: Five Number Summary and Box-and-Whisker Plots

front.title: Five Number Summary
front.question: What are the five values in a five number summary?

cards.back: Minimum, First Quartile (Q1), Median (Q2), Third Quartile (Q3), Maximum

front.title: Box-and-Whisker Plot
front.question: What does a box-and-whisker plot visually represent?

cards.back: The five number summary: minimum, Q1, median, Q3, and maximum.  The box represents the interquartile range (IQR = Q3 - Q1), and the whiskers extend to the minimum and maximum values.

front.title: Calculating Quartiles
front.question: How do you calculate the quartiles in a data set?

cards.back: Sort the data.  The median is Q2. Q1 is the median of the lower half of the data, and Q3 is the median of the upper half. If the number of data points is even, the median is the average of the two middle values. For quartiles, use the average of the two surrounding values if necessary.

front.title: Interquartile Range (IQR)
front.question: What is the interquartile range?

cards.back: The difference between the third quartile (Q3) and the first quartile (Q1): IQR = Q3 - Q1
